notes.text:
Red Hat JBoss A-MQ 6.3, which fixes multiple security issues and includes several bug fixes and enhancements, is now available from the Red Hat Customer Portal.

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having a security impact of Important. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which gives a detailed severity rating, is available for each vulnerability from the CVE link(s) in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
Red Hat JBoss A-MQ, based on Apache ActiveMQ, is a standards-compliant messaging system that is tailored for use in mission critical applications.

Red Hat JBoss A-MQ 6.3 is a minor product release that updates Red Hat JBoss A-MQ 6.2.1, and includes several bug fixes and enhancements. Refer to the Release Notes document, available from the Product Documentation link in the References section, for a list of these changes.

Security Fix(es):

It was found that Apache Shiro uses a default cipher key for its "remember me" feature. An attacker could use this to devise a malicious request parameter and gain access to unauthorized content. (CVE-2016-4437)

A denial of service flaw was found in the way Spring processes inline DTD declarations. A remote attacker could submit a specially crafted XML file that would cause out-of-memory errors when parsed. (CVE-2015-3192)

It was found that bouncycastle is vulnerable to an invalid curve attack. An attacker could extract private keys used in elliptic curve cryptography with a few thousand queries. (CVE-2015-7940)

Refer to the Product Documentation link in the References section for installation instructions.
notes.title: Details

document.title: Red Hat Security Advisory: Red Hat JBoss A-MQ 6.3 security update

notes.text: A denial of service flaw was found in the way Spring processes inline DTD declarations. A remote attacker could submit a specially crafted XML file that would cause out-of-memory errors when parsed.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: Framework: denial-of-service attack with XML input
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.

vulnerabilities.title: Framework: denial-of-service attack with XML input

notes.text: It was found that use of a JMS ObjectMessage does not safely handle user supplied data when deserializing objects. A remote attacker could use this flaw to execute arbitrary code with the permissions of the application using a JMS ObjectMessage.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: ObjectMessage: unsafe deserialization
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: A malicious message producer needs to authenticate to EAP in order to send messages. Also, the use of JMS ObjectMessage needs to be chosen by the developer of the application. Therefore this issue is rated as moderate.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
The References section of this erratum contains a download link (you must
log in to download the update).

If you do deploy a JMS publisher, and subscriber, and don't trust the messages sent to you by your clients, you could mitigate this issue by installing a Java agent which restricts the classes which can be deserialized. This is an article with the recommended approach:

https://access.redhat.com/solutions/2190911

You could also mitigate this issue using the features of the Java Virtual Machine added in JEP 290:

http://openjdk.java.net/jeps/290

cwe.name: Improperly Implemented Security Check for Standard

cwe.name: Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory ('Path Traversal')

notes.text: The Fileserver web application in Apache ActiveMQ 5.x before 5.14.0 allows remote attackers to upload and execute arbitrary files via an HTTP PUT followed by an HTTP MOVE request.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: activemq: Fileserver web application vulnerability allowing RCE
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: Red Hat JBoss A-MQ 6.3 , Red Hat JBoss Fuse 6.3, and Red Hat JBoss Fuse Service Works 6.0.0 do not provide the vulnerable component and are not affected by this flaw. Red Hat JBoss A-MQ 6.2.1 and Red Hat JBoss Fuse 6.2.1 disable the vulnerable component and as such are not vulnerable to this flaw. The fileserver component was first disabled in A-MQ 6.2.0 and Fuse 6.2.0. Users of older, unsupported versions of these products are strongly advised to observe the mitigation provided on this page.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
The References section of this erratum contains a download link (you must
log in to download the update).

Users are advised to use other FTP and HTTP based file servers for transferring blob messages. Fileserver web application SHOULD NOT be used in older version of the broker and it should be disabled (it has been disabled by default since 5.12.0). This can be done by removing (commenting out) the following lines from conf\jetty.xml file

<bean class="org.eclipse.jetty.webapp.WebAppContext">
    <property name="contextPath" value="/fileserver" />
    <property name="resourceBase" value="${activemq.home}/webapps/fileserver" />
    <property name="logUrlOnStart" value="true" />
    <property name="parentLoaderPriority" value="true" />
</bean>

vulnerabilities.title: activemq: Fileserver web application vulnerability allowing RCE
